prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The disks are well situated on the sky for ALMA observations in Band7. The extended configuration C34-5 is chosen providing 0.22''(15--30 AU radius) resolution. Since the dust hole radii are expected to be at least 25 AU, this resolution is sufficient to resolve the hole for each target. Band 7 is chosen because it provides the necessary spatial resolution and has shown to provide good constraints on the dust distribution, following Andrews et al. (2011) and Brown et al. (2009). The correlator is set to four spectral windows of 1875 MHz, to obtain the highest continuum sensitivity of the 7.5 GHz bandwidth (0.1 mJy/bm/10 minutes). The spectral windows are chosen such that both the upper and lower sideband fall in the high transparency part of Band 7. The windows in each band are set for the best compromise between continuum sensitivity and line spectral resolution of 1-2 km/s (required for obtaining spatial information of the gas, if detected). The windows are therefore centered at 345.1 and 343.225 GHz in the lower sideband and 355.1 and 356.975 in the upper sideband. With this choice, 12CO 3-2 in the lower and HCO+4-3 and HCN 4-3 in the upper sidebands are covered. Any gas emission inside and outside the dust hole that is bright enough for the channel sensitivity (9 mJy per 0.8 km/s channel) can be picked up through these lines serendipitously. For the brighter disks, the 12CO 3-2 gas emission can be as high as 100 mJy/bm km/s (Bruderer 2013).
To quantify the required sensitivity and resolvability of hole sizes, the 345 GHz flux is taken from the literature or from the fitted SED models. Using a generic model of a transitional disk continuum distribution based on Andrews et al. 2011, we derived the required S/N to image and resolve the dust holes (see Figure 3) down to 15 AU for the Taurus disks in this Science goal. Although the smallest holes are no longer directly visible, the null in the visibility plot indicates the presence of a hole. According to this model, most of the flux originates from the inner 120 AU of the disk. Spreading the total flux over <120 AU (<0.92" 4x4=16 beams), and requiring a S/N of at least 3sigma per beam, the total flux divided by number of beams has to be at least 48, requiring a total flux of at least 4.8 mJy for 0.1 mJy/bm noise, which is the rms level of 5 minute integrations. The overhead is 8-11 minutes per source.
The targets are grouped per star forming region for each Science Goal, due to the 10 degree distance restriction. Since each group contains targets of high and low 345 GHz flux, the sensitivity requirement is set to the minimum of 0.1 mJy/bm, so that even the faintest targets can be imaged.

Since the dust hole radii are expected to be at least 25 AU, this resolution is sufficient to resolve the hole for each target. The correlator is set to four spectral windows of 1875 MHz, to obtain the highest continuum sensitivity of the 7.5 GHz bandwidth (0.1 mJy/bm/5 minutes). Using a generic model of a transitional disk continuum distribution based on Andrews et al. 2011, we derived the required S/N to image and resolve the dust holes (see Figure 3) down to 25 AU for the Serpens disks in this Science goal. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The evolutionary phase from protoplanetary disks into planetary systems is formed by the transitional disks with large inner holes. For only ~20 of these disks the hole size has been confirmed by resolved submillimeter imaging, which makes it difficult to get good statistics on the hole size distribution. At the same time, the statistics on exoplanets at larger orbital radii are getting better through high-contrast AO imaging techniques, radial velocity observations and the Kepler mission. For a better understanding of the role of giant planets in disk evolution, a large unbiased sample of transitional disks with measured cavity sizes is essential. We propose here to use 5.1 hours of ALMA Band 7 continuum observations to survey a sample of 21 candidate giant planet host disks selected from complete infrared Spitzer surveys. With ALMA Cycle 2, dust holes down to 15 AU radius can be resolved within <10 minutes per target. The sample would more than double the existing sample of transitional disks with measured cavity radii. The complete sample will help to address statistical questions with exoplanetary studies and can be used for future high resolution gas studies with ALMA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Hawaii at Manoa, University of
European Space Astronomy Centre (ESAC), European Space Agency
